refnamediv.refpurpose: Assign an IP address to an interface

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The aq add interface address command assigns an IP address to an interface.
Note that you cannot add the primary IP address of a hardware entity using this command. Primary addresses are created by the add switch, add chassis, and add host commands.

listitem.para: Specify the hardware entity you wish to add the IP address to. You can use either the hardware label or the primary name for MACHINE, CHASISS and SWITCH.
Name of the interface where the IP address should be added.

Name to assign to the IP address in DNS. If you specify the --fqdn option only, and none of the IP options, then FQDN must refer to an existing address in DNS, and the IP address of this address is added to the interface. If you specify both --fqdn and an IP option, then a new DNS record will be created.
If the --network_environment is also specified, then the FQDN will be looked up/created in the DNS environment bound to NETENV. Otherwise the default DNS environment is used.

If --fqdn is not specified, then the value is generated from the local part of the primary name of the hardware and the name of the interface separated by a dash, in the same DNS domain as the primary name of the hardware.

The label (alias) of the address. Every interface may have exactly one address with no label. Every subsequent address must have a label that is unique on that interface. See section below for further information.
The hostname label is reserved for the primary IP address when the host uses Zebra.
Valid values for USAGE are system and zebra. system means that the address will be configured by the operating system. zebra means that the address will be managed by Zebra.
To enable IP failover support using Zebra, the same IP address must be assigned to multiple interfaces with the same LABEL.
Register the address in NETENV instead of the default network environment. A network containing the address must already exist in the given environment.
Specifying --network_environment also sets the DNS environment where FQDN is looked up or created.

refsection.title: Labels and virtual interfaces
refsection.para: Using the --label option will cause the IP address to show up as a virtual interface on Linux. For example, if IFACE is eth0 and LABEL is e0, then ifconfig will show you an interface called eth0:e0. The combined length of IFACE and LABEL must therefore be at most 15, one less than the maximum length of the name of a network interface.

Also note that such virtual interfaces are only emulated for some legacy tools like ifconfig. New style tools like ip addr list will show you just one interface with multiple addresses, and LABEL will show up as the label of the given IP address.

example.title: Add an auxiliary address to the second interface of host foo
example.programlisting: aq add interface address --machine foo.one-nyp.ms.com \ --interface eth1 \ --fqdn foo-e1.one-nyp.ms.com \ --ip 10.10.1.10

example.title: Add a second auxiliary address to the same interface
example.programlisting: aq add interface address --machine foo.one-nyp.ms.com \ --interface eth1 \ --label bar \ --fqdn foo-e1-bar.one-nyp.ms.com \ --ip 10.10.1.11

example.title: Add a Zebra-managed address, which is not the primary IP
example.programlisting:
aq add interface address --machine foo.one-nyp.ms.com \ --interface eth0 \ --label bar \ --usage zebra \ --fqdn foo-bar.one-nyp.ms.com \ --ip 10.10.1.12
aq add interface address --machine foo.one-nyp.ms.com \ --interface eth1 \ --label bar \ --usage zebra \ --fqdn foo-bar.one-nyp.ms.com \ --ip 10.10.1.12

example.title: Let the broker auto-generate the DNS entry
example.programlisting: aq add interface address --switch foo.one-nyp.ms.com \ --interface vlan110 \ --ip 10.10.1.1
example.para: The broker will add foo-vlan110.one-nyp.ms.com to the DNS using IP address 10.10.1.1.
